title: World's top 10 sexiest buildings [Photos]
text:
Monday, July 13, 2015 08:00 AM EDT World's top 10 sexiest buildings Previous Next 
Can a building be called sexy? When it's modelled after Beyonce's booylicious curves, it can! Design firm Elenberg Fraser recently announced they would be constructing a building in Melbourne, Australia inspired by Beyonce and her 'Ghost' music video. The 68-storey Premiere Tower will feature apartments, a hotel and retail space. The Australian building won't be the first inspired by celebrity curves, though. Mississauga, Ont. is home to the Absolute Towers, designed by Chinese firm MAD and nicknamed the 'Marilyn' buildings for their curved shape reminiscent of Marilyn Monroe. We list the world's 10 sexiest buildings in our gallery. Premiere Tower, Melbourne: Design firm Elenberg Fraser will be constructing a building in Australia inspired by Beyonce and her 'Ghost' music video. The 68-storey Premiere Tower will feature 660 apartments, a hotel and retail space. No completion date for the project has been revealed. (WENN.com/Elenberg Fraser/YouTube) 
Absolute Towers, Mississauga, Ont.: The 56-storey residential Absolute Towers in the heart of Mississauga have gained international attention for their curvy shape and have been nicknamed the "Marilyn" towers after late actress Marilyn Monroe. The towers were among the winners of the Best Tall Building in Americas 2012 honour by the Chicago-based Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat. (Tom Arban/CTBUH/2012 FOX/Handouts) 
Palace of Versailles, France: When Louis XIV moved from Paris to Versailles, he began to transform a royal hunting lodge into one of the grandest palaces in the world. Over the years, the palace expanded to 700 rooms, 67 staircases and 2,153 windows. Today, Versailles is open to tourists who want to discover its opulent rooms, lavish fountains and gardens, and the iconic Hall of Mirrors. Even Kim Kardashian and Kanye West can appreciate the appeal of Versailles: they held their May 2014 wedding rehearsal dinner at the palace. (Fotolia/Giancarlo Giammetti Instagram) 
Al Bahar Towers, Abu Dhabi: The Al Bahar Towers love to catch some rays. The 29-storey buildings have shading devices that automatically move to catch the sun and protect from solar glare. The moving shades have helped reduce the building's air conditioning costs. What's sexier than saving energy? The buildings were presented with an innovation award in 2012 by the Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat and have received a Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) silver rating. (Aedas/CTBUH/Handout) 
Burj Al Arab, Dubai: Get away to the Burj Al Arab hotel, a luxury property in the shape of a sail where your every whim and desire can be fulfilled. The hotel stands on its own artificial island, has a helipad on its 201-metre-tall roof and is just a private bridge walk away from a white sand beach. The hotel was completed in 1999 and was designed by WKK Architects. Canadian engineer Rick Gregory managed construction. (Fotolia) 
30 St Mary Axe, London: This building, nicknamed The Gherkin, sits in the centre of London's financial district and is adorned in elegant shades of black, grey, silver and gold. London's new kid on the block, it was completed in 2003, is considered one of the best examples of contemporary architecture in the city. A number of energy-saving initiatives were taken when building The Gherkin and, as such, it uses only half the energy a building of its size normally would. (Fotolia) 
Neuschwanstein Castle, Germany: Construction on this Romanesque Revival Bavarian castle started in 1869, having been commissioned by Ludwig II of Bavaria. After his death in 1886, the castle was opened to the public. Today, it is considered an iconic building of the Romantic period. (Fotolia) 
Lloyd's Building, London: London's Lloyd's Building - also known as the Inside-Out Building - bares all, with ducts, stairs and water pipes on the outside of the building to maximize inside space. It is the home of insurance company Lloyd's of London and was designed by Richard Rogers. It was completed in 1986. (Fotolia) 
Turning Torso, Stockholm: The Turning Torso is the tallest building in the Nordic countries with a height of 190 metres. Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava designed the building based on one of his sculptures, the Twisting Torso, a piece of marble sculpted in the form of a turning human body. This private residence took four years to complete, with the official inauguration of the iconic building taking place in August 2005. (Fotolia) 
Lipstick Building, New York City: Pucker up for a smooch at Manhattan's Lipstick Building, named for the tube of lipstick the building resembles. At one time, Bernie Madoff operated his Ponzi scheme from the 17th floor of the Lipstick Building. (Shutterstock)
